Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2015 10:54AM Kessala wrote: I was diagnosed Stage IV from the beginning in October, 2005. From Christmas of 2005 and every Christmas since then I've wondered if this will be the last one. Every year I wonder if it's worth the effort to put up all our decorations. Three years ago I inherited an artificial Christmas tree from my parents so now we display two full-size trees in our house. Instead of thinking it's the last Christmas, I find I'm adding even MORE to our celebrations! I'm sure a time will come when I don't feel up to going through the effort of decorating. But not yet. It took me a few days to get all the Christmas items unpacked and displayed but it's so worth it. The decorations make me smile. I can still manage to make this house look like Santa threw up in it. LOL Kessala

Posts.Content: May 29, 2015 09:21AM Kessala wrote: Making a Stage IV breast cancer announcement to friends and family isn't for everyone.  I was diagnosed at Stage IV right at the start in October, 2005.  I decided to hold off telling anyone about this except for Hubby of course until we had a treatment plan. When I found out I'd be taking hormonals, not lose my hair and would appear absolutely healthy I decided not to tell anyone else! My parents had health issues of their own to deal with.  Hubby and I live hundreds of miles from our families.  Our communication is typically via telephone or email.  Family and friends are unaware of my numerous medical appointments.  No one knew I was hospitalized overnight when I had a mastectomy. To this day no one other than medical people and my husband knows I have cancer, much less that I'm terminal.  And I love it!  What a relief to not have anyone fawning over me, talking about me behind my back, emailing me "cures" they discovered on the Internet, constantly asking how I'm doing.  No one treats me any differently than they ever have because I appear as my normal self. I've been on my first chemotherapy, Xeloda, for almost two years now so I've lost no hair and no one is any the wiser.  My intention is to keep my secret until there comes a time when I don't feel as well and it's becoming obvious something is wrong with me.  I've always been a very private person.  Handling my diagnosis this way is perfect for me. Kessala
Posts.Title: Telling (or not telling) friends and family ABeautifulSunset steelrose

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2015 08:25AM Kessala wrote: I've been on Xeloda for almost two years now and my eyes and nose are constantly dripping.  I'm not congested, don't sneeze, have no infections.  As I understand it, this is simply another side effect of Xeloda.  I just keep tissues handy.  What else can you do, right? Kessala

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2016 11:24AM Kessala wrote: MrsM, I don't know of any statistics. I just want to say I was diagnosed Stage IV right off the bat too. I also had a mastectomy about one week before spine mets were discovered. I am over 10 years from my diagnosis and I honestly believe having a mastectomy is one reason I'm still here. I think reducing my tumor burden helped, at least for a few years. Now, ten years out, a great deal of my skeleton is involved and I'm dealing with liver mets. But I believe I got extra time due to that mastectomy. You've asked an interesting question. I look forward to the responses you get. Kessala

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2015 12:12PM Kessala wrote: I've been getting Xgeva injections since September, 2011.  Prior to that I received Zometa infusions starting in November, 2005.  I was diagnosed with bone mets October, 2005. Because I've been receiving these bone medications for so many years I've talked Oncologist into backing off on the Xgeva to four times per year.  She was okay with this after I told her my worries about femur fractures (something I've only read about but it's something that concerns me). My December, 2014 PET/CT scan showed increase in two areas of bone mets so I'm back to getting Xgeva every six weeks now.  I've never experienced side effects from Xgeva.  I did have flu-like symptoms from my initial Zometa infusion and occasional knee pain in the few days following Zometa.  I've been living with bone mets for just over 9 years and I'm doing well.  I guess all that bone strengthening is helping despite my worries. Kessala
Posts.Title: Xgeva users - step up naturegirl2 Suesbooby2

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2009 11:28AM Kessala wrote: My oncologist hasn't even SAID the word "mammogram" to me since my Stage IV diagnosis in 2005. While I'm sure some Stage IV patients feel better continuing with their mammograms I personally see no reason to go on a witch hunt for additional cancer.  I mean I already have terminal breast cancer so what's the point.  If I were to develop another primary tumor in my remaining breast (I had one breast removed in 2005) I figure the treatment I'm taking now will handle it. Kessala

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2008 10:50AM - edited Nov 4, 2008 02:53PM by Kessala It's absolutely true that you shouldn't talk while your blood pressure is being taken.  There's one nurse at my Onc's office who is a real Chatty Cathy.  She peppers her conversation with questions even as she's taking my blood pressure.  The last time she did this and told me my bp was a bit high I said haven't you ever known people having their bp taken shouldn't talk?  Her reply was, I wasn't asking you to talk. I began to imitate her patter: "Did you have a lot of Trick Or Treaters?"  "Have you seen the Christmas displays in the stores already?" She was speechless.  She hadn't realized she continually asked me nonsense questions as she pumped the bp cuff!  I hope she learned something. Kessala

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2013 12:01PM Kessala wrote: Calico,  I also have cracks in the crevices of both my thumbs.  From Xeloda.  The cracks are deep enough so they bleed.  One thing that's worked for me to immediately relieve the pain and let you live semi-normally is to apply Krazy Glue to the cracks. Yes, Krazy Glue!  Hubby has deep finger cracks every winter and the only thing that helps is to coat them with layers of Krazy Glue.  The product doesn't bother your skin, the pain is immediately relieved, no stinging.  Of course the layer of glue wears off within a day or two.  I simply re-apply as needed.  Krazy Glue works SO MUCH better than New-Skin Liquid Bandage (which we've also tried).  It may be worth a try, especially if you've had to resort to using finger cots.    Kessala
Posts.Title: Recovery Time for Hand and Foot Side Effect CalicoCat DancingVeggie

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2014 04:04PM Kessala wrote: I had three weeks of radiation to my spine for pain in September, 2011.  I don't recall which vertebrae but it was midway up my back. The radiation oncologist told me he wouldn't expect me to have any side effects.  I was laid on my back and the machine rotated below me and zapped me from below.  I wasn't even home from my first radiation appointment before the nausea hit.  It took me a few days to realize the radiation was causing my nausea.  When I told the radiation oncologist about it he looked at me sideways as if I was making this up!  WTF?  (Oh, relax ladies, it stands for "Why the face?") Radiation oncologist gave me Zofran and told me to take it one hour before my radiation appointments.  It was a miracle.  Kessala
Posts.Title: Radiation on Spine Iamstronger KiwiCatMom

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2013 04:49PM Kessala wrote: Calico, Thank you for the praise but I can't claim that the Krazy Glue idea is mine.   I read about this in Reader's Digest back in the 1990s in an article written by a dermatologist.  Apparently using Krazy Glue is a common thing among athletes when they have cuts happen during sporting events.  Hubby tried it on his cracked "winter fingers" and it works like a charm.  At least for a day or two.  It does wear and wash off so it has to be re-applied.    Kessala

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2013 03:04AM Kessala wrote: I had hand/foot syndrome start 10 days into my first cycle of Xeloda.  I had to stop taking the drug so my hands and feet could heal.  I had pain on the soles of my feet for a full seven days after stopping Xeloda.  Nothing I did relieved the pain.  Nothing.  I just had to hobble around here and live with it.   The information on the Xeloda web site is lame at best.  What the manufacturer doesn't tell you is that the hand/foot syndrome is caused by Xeloda leaking out of the capillaries and into surrounding tissue.  What you're experiencing is a chemical burn from within.  No amount of ice packs, avoiding the sun or applying hand lotion to the surface of the skin will either prevent or heal hand/foot syndrome.   As far as I'm concerned all the instructions on how to "manage" hand/foot is just something to keep the patients busy.  As if being remiss in applying hand lotion is the reason we've got hand/foot syndrome.     Kessala

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2014 10:38PM Kessala wrote: I love this thread!  Raro, stripping myself naked to scrub the shower stall is the only way I do it!  It's so easy, who cares how much Soft Scrub I get splattered with while washing the shower walls and I finish up by taking a shower in my sparkling shower stall.  Works great! My embarrassment is the fact I haven't washed any windows in this house since August, 2009.  I know this because my parents flew up to visit us that month so I know I washed windows before their visit.  Mom died in November, 2009 and my dad was too ill with Parkinson's disease to travel alone so August, 2009 was their final visit to our house. Our windows are so dirty with cobwebs and crud sometimes I think it's foggy outside and then realize it's dirty windows, not fog.  We even have newer windows that tilt in for cleaning and still they sit neglected.  I'm tempted to hire someone to come clean our windows just so we can head into winter with clean glass but then think maybe tomorrow I'll wash just one window.  The following day I'll wash just one window.  And so on. But I doubt it.  Ha! Kessala

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2014 02:13PM Kessala wrote: Any co-pay plan offered by drug manufacturers only lowers the cost to the patient, not to the medical insurer.  BLV-NJ is right to be concerned about her job security.  I worked for a much smaller company with self-insurance.  Each month it was my job to reconcile a report of each employee's medical expenses paid by the company.  I don't know if any employee was laid off due to high medical costs but the company president and the board of directors were certainly aware of which employees were costing them the most money. Kessala

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2017 06:46PM - edited Mar 8, 2017 06:58PM by Kessala SusanR, I've had multiple PET scans over the past eleven years of dealing with mets. My most recent PET scan was done last week. NEVER in all that time have I EVER been told I shouldn't walk into the clinic from my car or be wheeled into the Imaging Department via wheelchair! That's so silly it's laughable! By requesting you not to exercise during the 24 hours prior to your PET scan they mean don't go to the gym, don't run a race, don't overdo vacuuming or floor scrubbing. Live your normal life, walk your dog down the block and back, prepare supper for your other family members, clean up the kitchen afterwards. But to skip the walk from the parking lot and be wheeled into the scanning room is such nonsense. I'd love to have been given those instructions by a well-meaning but obviously new medical worker. I would have laughed in their face! Other than the over-zealous instructions you've been given I think you'll find having a PET scan is mostly boring. I usually doze off before the scan and during the scan. You won't feel sick, the radioactive glucose injection doesn't make you feel any different. It's an easy-peasy procedure. It certainly doesn't require you to act like a mannequin prior to the scan. Kessala
Posts.Title: New PET scan warning -- to stay warm? TarheelMichelle TarheelMichelle

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2015 10:24AM Kessala wrote: I was diagnosed at Stage IV right off the bat.  I had a single bone met in my lower spine. I was on Zometa for a total of 6 years.  I had it monthly for a couple years and then four times per year for four years.  I refused the scanning Oncologist recommended.  I figured no symptoms, no pain, so why scan? Six years later I had the world's worst backache out of the clear blue.  I had to be scanned.  The bone mets were now in my entire spine.  The backache was due to two broken vertebra due to mets. I was then switched to Xgeva and was getting it monthly.  I was on monthly Xgeva for a couple more years.  Due to reading about side effects (femur fractures) I asked Oncologist if I could back off on getting Xgeva so often.  She let me back off to every 12 weeks. At my very next scan two areas of bone mets showed new activity.  Oncologist immediately changed my Xgeva injections to every 6 weeks and that's what I'm currently doing. I've been receiving bone strengthening infusions or injections for almost 10 years, sometimes as often as every month and sometimes as little as four times per year.  No one knows what to expect as a result of getting these medications for so many years.  There is no data that I'm aware of. However, the fact my bone mets showed new growth when we backed off the Xgeva it scared Oncologist into giving it to me more often. Kessala

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2015 06:15PM Kessala wrote: The longer I live with Stage IV breast cancer the more blunt I become. Had that nurse made such a comment to me I would have blasted right back to her that her words are hurtful and unnecessary and not something she should have said. And I don't care how loud my voice becomes and who overhears me. I tend to embarrass my husband who comes with me to every appointment. I told him the older I get and the longer I live with cancer I feel less and less like I have to spare anyone's feelings. I was wondering if you reported the nurse's words to a superior and then read that you had. And that superior gave a totally unsatisfactory answer. Interesting the nurse is no longer working at your clinic. Hmmmm, I wonder why? (said sarcastically). You weren't the only patient who complained about her "honesty". Remember we are paying customers in this "game". Doctors and nurses and support staff work for us. Speak up if someone acts like a jerk. If it weren't for our dollars these people wouldn't have jobs. I don't suffer fools. Kessala

Doctor keeps track of me by symptoms and scans. Kessala

Posts.Content: May 6, 2016 12:41PM Kessala wrote: Thanks, Fitz. I guess I'll go first. I didn't finish A Man Called Ove. I only got about 2/3rds of the way through the book before giving up. I didn't like the book, found nothing "hilarious" about it. Typically I find if a book is described as hilarious or laugh-out-loud funny I never find that to be true. What I didn't like about the story was that Ove is a widower. He spends his days thinking about his late wife, living inside his head and repeatedly trying to commit suicide. As a Stage IV breast cancer patient all I could think was is this how my husband will be after I'm gone? Disengaged from the world and always looking for a way out of this life? As a 65 year old woman I was also stunned that the author considered Ove, a man in his 50s, as an old curmudgeon! From my prospective someone who is considered a curmudgeon is probably in their 80s! Obviously this is an opinion from someone with a terminal illness and who, in her mid-60s, doesn't think 50s is curmudgeon territory. I love the idea of being part of a book club though. This first book just didn't float my boat. Kessala
Posts.Title: Book Club: A Man Called Ove, response questions Fitztwins Fitztwins

Posts.Content: May 7, 2016 06:22PM Kessala wrote: Interesting thoughts, 50sgirl. I see what you mean about all those failed suicide attempts where Ove rather purposely didn't carry through. It's the fact he obviously thought about, planned and partially completed repeated attempts to kill himself that bothered me. All right already, either die or quit trying. And all the while I transferred my thoughts to my future widower husband and I simply didn't like or care about Ove anymore. Kessala
